segments.text: ...rings, only they don't ring.
They don't ring.
And so the result is, I'm always looking at my watch, looking to tape frantically, so we only end up taping 15 minutes it doesn't appear.
Concerning deep ocean mining, are you optimistic or not optimistic about the ability to do this?
Well, I think it would be a tremendous engineering feat if they can do it.
I think, again, it's an economic question.
the manganese nodules that they're chasing.
I guess the big problem with that is they're waiting for the price of manganese to go up high enough.
And then it'll become economically feasible.
I'm sure there's a whole bunch of different things they can go out and try and scavenge up.
And of course, it's
environmental, I mean an economic question.
Near shore resource recovery, you know, of course down in Texas you know about the oil.
On the east coast they've been dredging up gravel for a long time.
I'm not really up on that so I don't know what other kinds of things they can run around and harvest.
It wasn't deep ocean mining, but of course the Germans were going to pay off the First World War debt with gold.
I mean, there's a tremendous reservoir of material out there.
And whether you can extract it or not, it's straight down to the bottom line.
Do you make money at it or don't you make money at it?
So I guess when other stocks or materials
get expensive enough to try and get them out of the ocean.
Now, I have a series of questions concerning undergraduate training, which ought to be...

In terms of training for oceanography, do you think it's better to go and take a degree in the hard sciences and then come to oceanography late, or to go through a general undergraduate training in oceanography, or what?
Well, this is a
rhetorical problem we have in this department time and time again, because we're the only ones that have an undergraduate degree in oceanography.
If you look at the players in the game, at least my age or older, or even some of them younger, we all came from another area and ended up in oceanography.
I'm not really sure what kind of a
approach to take.
Again, I don't see any particular desirability to go one way or the other.
I wouldn't want to see us get stamped into the mold of going one way or the other.
I still think you've got to be, you've got to have the depth in one area, and then hopefully broaden your sight somewhat.
it gets extremely difficult talking to people with just the broad brush view on things, because you always end up talking about the nitty-gritty somewhere along the line, and then you lose them.
So I think we'll see recruitment coming into the field the same way as it has in the past, and that is people coming out of a discipline in the regular, quote, sciences,
and then playing in the ocean, using their expertise in the ocean.
It's kind of interesting if you look at people, again, my age or older, which is, what, 39, I think.
I think, by and large, most of them had something to do with the ocean before they became a scientist.
They grew up on it, they sailed on it, they swam in it, or something like this, and some sort of a fascination
that way got them into the field.
I guess I can look back on my own, you know, how I got into the business was that I never thought they would pay people to do this kind of thing, you know.
And it's, you know, a very fascinating and interesting area.
And having come from a family that used to work for a living, I was rather surprised, you know, that you could in fact make a living doing this sort of thing.
So I don't see any
any real need to get very excited about whether we should do the recruitment the way most of us have come into it or whether you should do it through the undergraduate route.
The only thing I'm afraid of is that our undergraduates don't have enough depth in any one discipline.
And I hate like heck to see everybody come up that way.
We've been a little bit lax here.
We've been trying to find out what's happened to our graduates.

I don't think it's, well, if you go through any scientific discipline, if you look at the guy's major as an undergraduate and find out where he ends up, very few of them really go on into graduate school and that thing.
So the fact that we know that a lot of our undergraduates don't end up in oceanography shouldn't really be disappointing, because the other disciplines have the same

track record but if you happen to well it goes back to when the person makes a decision on what he wants to be you know when he grows up if for some reason somebody can come into you know a 15 or 16 year old kid says I'm going to be an oceanographer and if he really knows what being an oceanographer is and if that's really what he wants to do and maybe
getting them here as an undergraduate and then prodding them to get his expertise in a certain area, that's probably OK.
But for an ordinary run-of-the-mill kid, heck, most of them don't even know what they want to do when they get to graduate school.
And so I'm not sure we're doing anybody a favor or a disservice by taking them on as undergraduates.
But I still think.
you need some depth in some area if you're going to be a practicing scientist.

Probably, I'd hazard a guess, or I would like to think, that the people that come through here as undergraduates, if they go into whatever they go into, and if they ever get in a situation where they have to make decisions that affect us later on, at least they know more about what we're talking about.
i.e., they go into government or something like this.
And if they end up in some rather remotely connected field, then I think you'd look at their undergraduate training as a broadening experience, which I think is what...
I think we'd like to see that come out of colleges.
I don't think we're really running vocational schools.
I hate like heck to think that we're just running training programs to train people for jobs.
I'd like to take the more philosophical point of view that this is an age that kids are developing ideas.
They're growing up.
Well, like when I went away to college, I went away from home.
was in an area where it was rather forgiving.
We all make mistakes.
And that's a time that I guess you've got to do them.
Preferably, you can do them then and not have them count.
And so the philosophy behind an undergraduate program is something that we haven't really talked about in this department.
Like I said, we are the only ones in the United States, I think, with a degree-granting program in oceanography on the undergraduate level.
but I don't think we've ever seriously tried to track down all our graduates and see what happens to them.

I have the feeling that we end up graduating a very small percentage of the entering freshmen, but that's sort of a trick in how they count credits in this university here, because it turns out that many of the biologically oriented people that come through as undergraduates end up with
either joint degrees in zoology and oceanography, or if they missed the requirement along the way, it turns out that they don't have to do anything and they get a degree in zoology.
So then they fall out of our statistics the way we keep them now.
And probably the same thing happened in chemistry and probably physics, too.
But again, I think to be a practicing player,
in the oceanography game, I think you've got to have a depth in one area.
Because oceanography is kind of a problem to really define it as a discipline.
It's kind of an amorphous field.
And we've seen an awful lot of people sort of trooping in.
And they leave a few footprints, and they end up somewhere else.
And they might even come back.
So it's not such a rigid thing.
discipline.
Well, maybe the other fields are.
I haven't had any experience with the other fields, but I don't think it's all that rigid of an area.
Now, in that sense, what direction is oceanography going to go?
What are the so-called hot fields in oceanography?
I may use this word.
You know, at one time, for example, nuclear engineering in oceanography was identified with each other in terms of career opportunities.
What now?
Okay, as far as
career opportunities go, we don't have the real brightness that we thought we had a few years ago.
We're probably a little bit brighter than as far as career opportunities.
Broadly speaking, I think, well, perhaps one of the, at least in the biological area, one of the major
areas that's going to expand over the next decade or so is predictability.
And this has been prodded by the environmental problem.
Well, the money to move down this avenue, I think, has been prodded by the environmental problem.
If you go back and look at some of the older literature, of course, this is what they've been trying to do all along,
predictability, the ordering of the knowledge, you know, both action wise and how can you predict what's going to happen.
And again, in biology, that's probably the big area.
But that's such a broad area.
I mean, we can use it, again, to play the food for the hungry millions game.
We can look at it from, you know, if you stress the system, what happens to the populations involved, i.e., these species?
You know, does species A fall out?
You know, who becomes dominant?
There's a couple really big major questions in biological oceanography that haven't been answered.
And quite frankly, I don't know how the heck you can answer them.
And that's one of the things that sort of prods us is that we know that species composition
changes by environmental perturbations, but we don't know if that really has any effect on productivity.
If you want to sort of sidestep the whole issue, again, going back to this thing I was telling you about Heathrow Airport, we know that
that there's codfish off Greenland.
And if the average sea surface temperature drops a half a degree centigrade or a degree centigrade, they're going to disappear.
Now, if you're a cod connoisseur, it's a disaster.
But maybe you end up with a lot of sea urchins out there.
So maybe the actual productivity won't change, just that we don't recognize the end product as a resource, unless you're a sea urchin connoisseur.
So I think there's a lot of...

large questions with ramifications of them that are questions that you can narrow down enough to work on and do an experiment, collect some data, play the hypothesis testing game to keep us busy for an awful long time.
But I think the so-called hot areas are probably the predictability and the modeling aspect.
Those are probably true for all the areas in oceanography, not just biology.
I sort of get annoyed with computer simulation as an answer to everything, but I did buy one of those things, which is a tremendous little toy.
And that's getting pretty close to it.
The whole thing about science, I guess, is the predictability, the hierarchical ordering of knowledge.
We're playing the game just like all the other areas.
The other high-energy physics, for instance, I mean, they've gotten down to looking at such little tiny things that I personally don't find that very satisfying.
I like to be able to hold my hand when I'm working with it.
One of the nicer things about oceanography is that it's still a relatively young field
You can sort of keep up with the literature.
It's kind of a hassle.
It takes a fair amount of my time, but as opposed to some of the other disciplines, I mean, boy, I would be pity to the kids getting into molecular biology and all that sort of stuff.
Just the backlog of information these kids have to sieve through is just frightening.
I try to keep a fair number of journals.
Mainly if they don't pass my desk, I don't send them.
But I used to read Biochem Med by Phys Acta.
And back when I was a beginning graduate student, each year you had about 18, well, 20, maybe 28 inches on the shelf.
Well, nowadays, the same journal, if you get the various series, there's probably three or four shelves.
And I don't know how you keep up with that sort of stuff.
But that's, maybe I'm lazy.
I don't want to spend all my time reading it.
The other thing about oceanography is that I think there's still some important discoveries to be made.
The people at Woods Hole were kind of stuck up about this, and they said, oh, what the heck are you reading literature for?
Because you're writing it.
You don't have to read it.
You should be the guy right up there in the front and writing it all.
But who can predict
breakthroughs are solutions to big problems or something like this.
But I still think there's some reasonably large size problems that are definable right now in biological oceanography that are unanswered.

And in that way it's kind of, I hate to use the word challenging, but I guess that's what I mean as opposed to some of the other disciplines where they keep poking and poking and poking and breakthroughs are totally unprotected.
I mean, you're really flailing around in the dark trying to find that big thing that's going to propel you to the Nobel Prize.
I don't think anybody in oceanography is ever going to have to worry about that one, but there are still some nice, fairly definable problems in oceanography to be worked on.
For example?
Well, the whole thing, what does species composition do it?
honest-to-goodness production in an area.
The interaction between energy flow and population dynamics on the species level.

This one, the only thing that's discouraging about that area is that people have been hassling this thing for an awful long time, so somebody's got the right answer for the wrong reason and he doesn't know it.
So maybe that wouldn't be as
rewarding as, you know, stumbling onto something completely new.
But as opposed to some of the other disciplines, of course, I mean that's a minor problem.
Again, the other disciplines are so damn specialized now that I just pity the poor kids getting into it.
But I think that's one of the big ones.
Okay, the one we're playing around with right now is how to
Organisms on the bottom of the ocean make a living.
If you dredge up a clam that's a half inch in diameter, he might be 50 years old.

Some of the other things that I'm constantly surprised at, and I've seen it time and time again, is you dredge up some of these fish from a couple thousand meters down, which most people have only seen pictures of, and they never read the scale on the bottom, and they're only this big.
But they might be 50 years old, too.
And how do organisms make a living out there?
I think it's a major unanswered question.
Again, going back to the food for the million, there is a genus, cyclotone, I think is the correct pronunciation of it.
There's probably more of those things than anything else in the world, that species than any other fish species in the world.
There must be billions and billions and billions of metric tons out there.
The only trouble is there's only one per cubic meter, so you can't catch them.
But that's probably the fish production in the ocean.
There's probably more biomass tied up in that mid-water genus than everybody else.
You probably can't catch them.
Again, economically, it's not feasible to catch them.
But again, every time I'm on a boat where they drag up one of those things, it's...
I'm always impressed.
Mainly because, I don't think I have the book here, but Marshall, I think, was the one who wrote it.
No, Norman, History of Fishers.
And he's got these nice color plates in there.
They show these guys with these big teeth and the big eyes and all the four to fours and stuff like this.
But they're only two inches long.
You always have some pleasant surprises.
And like I said, I've seen that, I can't
Hundreds of times, but I'm still impressed with it every time I see it.
What about declining fields of oceanography?
Physical oceanography, for example.
It seems like people don't work in physical oceanography anymore at the same rate they used to.
Well, I think we've seen a major shift, and this is kind of a touchy point in this department because we have a large number of people that call themselves physical oceanographers.
But they're really applied mathematicians.
And we see an awful lot of numerical modeling trying to explain phenomena that go on in the ocean.
My major gripe is that an awful lot of the practitioners of that particular kind of science don't go to sea.
I don't think they know what, I don't think they really grasp what's going on out there.
And again, they're in an area in theoretical physical oceanography, fluid hydrodynamics primarily, again, where they're beginning to get down to how many angels can stand on a head of the pen.
It seems that they work the field over very well so that on the broad aspects, the parts that are
mostly utilizable by anybody else, i.e.
a merchant marine, the weather people, and things like this.

A lot of these things are reasonably well known, and so now they're getting down to the real fine-grained nitty-gritty, which I'm sure must be interesting to them, otherwise they wouldn't do it, but its relationship to other areas in science is greatly diminished.
So that we see a lot of
emphasis on physical oceanography in this department.
Probably half the faculty is what I would call physical oceanographers here, but very few of them go to sea.
Most of them, not most of them, a fair number of them are looking at extremely small scale phenomena, which as a biological oceanographer doesn't do much for me.
I'm still stuck with
large-scale motions in the ocean.
You know, worried about movements through the thermocline, the picnic line, things like this.

But these people are worrying about even smaller-scale stuff than that, so that they're... Again, they don't have a heck of a lot to tell me about anything that I have a problem with, although I fully appreciate that most of the biological problems in coastal waters is driven by the physical processes.
But again, what they're telling me or what they're working on doesn't help me with that at all.
There are people who work with that, but it seems to be a minor concern of the physical oceanographers now as compared to, say, 10 or 15 years ago.
Now, I have another question along that line, too, Robert.
Roger Revell has suggested what's wrong with the modern oceanographers.
He no longer gets his feet wet.
Would you agree with that?
Yep.
Okay.
Okay.

He has also suggested that one of the problems with marine biologists is that with the advent of the computers and the vast amount of data coming in, that people don't have familiarity anymore with their data.
All they have familiarity with are data sheets.
Yeah, you see a lot of that too.
And so then you think that perhaps, I don't want to use the, I don't, the question is not well worded.
I don't mean that oceanography has become too sophisticated.
but that possibly more field work should occur in oceanography.
Yeah, I agree with that.
One of my criteria is to accept the graduate student.
He's got three things he or she has to be able to do.
They have to be able to do things with their hands.
They have to be able to do things with their heads.
By God, they've got to be able to go to sea.
I mean, if they don't go to sea, then I won't touch them.
Okay, I go to sea, oh, let's see, next year I'm scheduled 70 days out of the year, and I went through a tabulation for somebody else a little while ago.
Okay, I've been in the field for 13 years, two and a half years I was a bureaucrat in Washington, and in aggregate I've got something like 24 months at sea, which, um,
Well, if you're a mariner, of course, that doesn't mean much, but compared to most of the people I talk to around here, that's an awful lot of time in the city.
And anybody that I'm going through the educational process with, they're going to be field-oriented people.
I've got some kids here, some graduate students, I guess they're not kids,
They grew up the same way that I did.
They were underwater.
One of them happens to be a blue water sailboat racing type.
But he's got a good head.
He remembered things.
And he's seen things.
He's felt things out in the ocean.
And he's got a lot of insight into some problems that people, again, we've got some biological oceanographers who never really have been to sea.
And it's taken them 15 years to get to the same state of development as this kid is.
Of course, he's been doing it for over 15 years too, but he hasn't been a professional in the business for 15 years.
Here's a guy starting out.
He'll probably finish up next winter.
And he's probably got as much innate feel for what's going on in the ocean that he's learned what the technical jargon is so he can describe it since he's been a student.
to match up to some of these 50-year-old people around here that have been in the business all their lives.
I think a lot of oceanographers have real problems because they don't go to sea.
They forget what's going out there.
And they're, well, I can sit here.
This happens to be one of my pet peeves, as you probably figured out.
And I've seen people whose idea of a
of the ocean is a matrix in a computer bank.
And they keep interrogating this matrix that they've generated there.
Sometimes they've even gotten some real data in to generate the matrix, but a lot of times they don't because the computers can't handle the real problems.
They're just too complex.
They're not fast enough.
It costs too much money to model it.
I really get annoyed at people who tell me about this or that, or they'll tell me that this measurement that I've done isn't really up to snuff.
There are better ways of doing it.
Yes, I know there are better ways of doing it, but you can't do them out there.
The instrument doesn't work, let's say.
And again, with the way the funding situation is going, unless you're extremely
queued about things, it's pretty tough to get students out to sea.
The government won't pay for it anymore.
Well, that was my next question.
What about ship time?
One of the problems with oceanographers who want to go to sea, it seems to me, is a limited amount of ship time available to institutions.
Well, I think, yeah, okay.
You can flip this coin both ways.
If you go and look at the proposals that they send in,
and how much money they need to run the ships.
It turns out that if we're going to run all our ships all year long, there's not enough money.
But it might also be true that there's not enough worthwhile seagoing science to keep all the ships busy.
We play this game every year.
Well, of course, now I take a partisan point of view being here in Washington.

in the University of Washington, but back when I was at NSF, we had a, we played the flip game, and the problem, well, one of the problems, one of the bureaucratic problems is that nobody has ever tried to figure out how much ship time was really required.
We just know that we seem to be spending an inordinately large amount of money for ship time for the science that goes on the ships.
Of course, you can rectify that by
One of two ways, you can cut down the ship time bucks so you can put in more dollars into the science that goes on the ships.

But in two and a half years at the Science Foundation, at least in the biological oceanography program, I don't think I've ever seen a worthwhile seagoing program that wasn't funded and given the ship time to do it.
And so you always end up, you know, one of the rhetorical questions was, if you had more money in biological oceanography, what would happen?
And the pan answer was you'd fund more incompetent scientists.
